facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 35 of 1970 filed in Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated May 22, 1969 of Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench in Cr. A. No. 132 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 22, 1969 of the Allahabad High Court,  Lucknow Bench  at Lucknow in Cr. A. No. 132 of 1967.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court allowed revision of Izhar Hussain on May 22, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant challenges the order of a learned single Judge of the Lucknow Bench of the Allahabad High Court dated May 22, 1969 allowing the revision of lzhar Hussain

facts.text: High Court set aside Sessions Judge, Barabanki order dated March 15, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: and after setting aside the order of the Sessions Judge, Barabanki dated March 15, 1967 as also that of the Additional District Magistrate

facts.text: High Court set aside Additional District Magistrate Judicial, Barabanki order dated January 11, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Barabanki dated March 15, 1967 as also that of the Additional District Magistrate  Judicial , Barabanki dated January 11, 1967,

facts.text: High Court directed Deputy Registrar to file complaint under S. 211 IPC against appellant for falsely charging Izhar Hussain with offences under ss. 323, 325/149, 147 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: directing the Deputy Registrar of the- High Court to file a companyplaint under S. 21 1, I.P.C. against the appellant for falsely charging Izhar Hussain with offences under ss. 323 and 325 read with S. 149 and under S. 147, I.P.C.

facts.text: FIR Ext. Ka-9 lodged by Kartar Singh s/o Shri Lachman Singh at PS Kotwali, Nawabganj, Barabanki on February 7, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that pursuant to the first information report  Ext. Ka-9  lodged by Kartar Singh s o Shri Lachman Singh at police station Kotwali Sub-District Nawabganj, District Barabanki on February 7, 1966,

facts.text: Izhar Hussain and others tried before Additional District Magistrate Judicial, Barabanki for offences under ss. 147, 323/149, 325/149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: lzhar Hussain respondent and some others were tried in the companyrt of the Additional District Magistrate  Judicial , Barabanki for offences under ss. 147, 323/149 and 325/149, I.P.C.

facts.text: Santokh Singh (appellant) appeared as PW.4 and deposed on September 3, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Several witnesses were examined in support of the prosecution case. Santokh Singh appellant appeared as P.W.4.

facts.text: Santokh Singh in examination-in-chief stated he saw Izhar Hussain in the marpit and identification parade.

anchor.surface_text: In his examination in chief, so far as relevant for our purpose, he had deposed on September 3, 1966 as follows - I had gone to the jail for identifying the accused persons. By putting his hand on Mohd, Zahir, Usman, Shahnshah, Puttan and Izhar Husain the witness stated, I had seen them in the marpit and thereafter in the identification parade in the jail-

facts.text: Santokh Singh in cross-examination stated he did not see Izhar Hussain among assailants that night and identified at instance of Octroi post people.

anchor.surface_text: In cross-examination, he had stated, inter alia I did number see among the assailants the accused lzhar Hussain present in Court. I did number happen to see this boy in that night. The men of the Octroi post said to me that Anwars son Izhar was also present among the assailants. I identified this boy in the jail at the instance of the people of the Octroi post.

facts.text: Additional District Magistrate acquitted all accused on November 30, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional District Magistrate trying the cases acquitted all the accused of the offences charged on November 30, 1966.

facts.text: Izhar Hussain aged about 13 years as per Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of his judgment. the learned Magistrate observed inter alia One of the accused lzhar Hussain is a boy aged about 13 years.

facts.text: Kartar Singh and Santokh Singh stated they had not seen Izhar Hussain at place of occurrence.

anchor.surface_text: It has been stated by Kartar Singh and- Santokh Singh that actually they had number seen him it the place of occurrence. Still Santokh Singh identified him before Shri A. P. Singh, Magistrate.

facts.text: Magistrate did not hold that Santokh Singh falsely charged Izhar Hussain or direct prosecution under S.211 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: It is numbereworthy that the Additional District Magistrate while acquitting the accused persons did number hold that Santokh Singh had falsely charged lzhar Hussain or any other accused persons, number did the learned Magistrate companysider it to be expedient in the interest of justice to prosecute Santokh Singh for an offence under s. 21 1, I.P.C.

facts.text: Izhar Hussain filed application under ss.476/479-A CrPC in January 1967 against Kartar Singh, Santokh Singh, R.D. Chowdhry.

anchor.surface_text: In January, 1967, lzhar Hussain presented an application in the companyrt of the Additional District Magistrate  Judicial , Barabanki under ss. 476/479-A, Cr-P.C.

facts.text: Additional DM rejected Izhar Hussain's application on January 11, 1967 citing Kuppa Goundan case.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional District Magistrate observed that after companysidering the evidence in the main case he had disbelieved the witnesses for the prosecution and had held lzhar Hussains prosecution to be false but...

facts.text: Sessions Judge dismissed Izhar Hussain's appeal on March 15, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Izhar Hussain took the matter on appeal to the companyrt of the Sessions Judge but with numberbetter fate. The Sessions Judge also... The appeal of Izhar Hussain was accordingly dismissed.

facts.text: Izhar Hussain filed revision under ss.435/439 CrPC to Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench.

anchor.surface_text: lzhar. Hussain thereupon took the matter to the Lucknow Bench of the Allahabad High Court on revision under ss. 435/439, Cr.P.C.

facts.text: High Court found Izhar Hussain falsely implicated, directed complaint under S.211 IPC against Santokh Singh due to trade rivalry.

anchor.surface_text: On this material, the High Court felt that it had been established beyond doubt that lzhar Hussain had been implicated falsely... There was thus a foul attempt to wreak vengeance against Izhar Hussains father by falsely implicating the minor boy and for this reason, it was directed that the companyplaint under s. 21 1, I.P.C. be filed against the appellant

facts.text: Kartar Singh and Santokh Singh were victims of the assault.

anchor.surface_text: Earlier the learned Magistrate had observed that Kartar Singh and Santokh Singh were obviously the victims of the assault.

facts.text: Izhar Hussain's father had trade rivalry with Santokh Singh and his master.

anchor.surface_text: Izhar Hussains father who carried on transport business through trucks and lorries had, according to the MO Court, trade rivalry with Santokh Singh and his master.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and set aside High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the foregoing discussion, we have numberhesitation in allowing this appeal and setting aside the order of.

facts.text: Kartar Singh did not name Izhar Hussain in FIR or identify in ID parade or trial court.

anchor.surface_text: Kartar Singh had number named Izhar Hussain as one of the assailants in the F.I.R. lodged by him, number did Kartar Singh identify Izhar Hussain as a culprit in the test identification parade or in the trial companyrt.

facts.text: Santokh Singh identified Izhar Hussain in test ID parade and trial court.

anchor.surface_text: Santokh Singh appellant, however, did identify lzhar Hussain as one of the participants in the crime in the test identification parade and also picked him up in the trial companyrt stating that he had also taken part in the crime.

facts.text: Additional DM did not consider proceedings under S.479A CrPC expedient.

anchor.surface_text: in spite of this companyclusion he had number directed any proceedings to be taken under s. 479-A, Cr.P.C., number had be ordered criminal prosecution of the three aforementioned witnesses.

facts.text: Sessions Judge applied principle from Kuppa Goundan case and dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Applying the said principle of law as laid down by their Lordships, it is obvious that the entire material was before the Court below and in spite of the fact that it arrived at the finding that the witness had perjured, it did number decide to proceed under Section 479-A, Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that giving false evidence as witness does not constitute falsely charging under S.211 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: the expression falsely charges. in this section, in our opinion, cannot mean giving false evidence as a prosecution witness against an accused person during the companyrse of a criminal trial.

facts.text: Izhar Hussain's participation in crime highly improbable as 13 year old boy.

anchor.surface_text: It was then observed that lzhar Hussain. a boy of 13 years had been falsely prosecuted in the case and that his participation in the crime was highly improbable, if number impossible.

facts.text: R.D. Chowdhry, SI, submitted charge sheet in collusion with Kartar Singh.

arguments.claim: Proceedings under s.476 CrPC are incompetent because the trial court did not record a finding under s.479A CrPC at the time of judgment despite disbelieving witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional District Magistrate observed that after considering the evidence in the main case he had disbelieved the witnesses for the prosecution and had held Izhar Hussains prosecution to be false but in spite of this conclusion he had not directed any proceedings to be taken under s. 479-A, Cr.P.C., nor had he ordered criminal prosecution of the three aforementioned witnesses. The proceedings under s. 476, Cr.P.C. were accordingly held incompetent.

arguments.claim: Direction to file complaint under s.211 IPC is unjustified, illegal, based on misreading evidence and erroneous view of law; appellant did not institute proceedings or falsely charge under s.211.

anchor.surface_text: In this Court, Shri Gupta has very forcefully contended that on the material on the record this direction is wholly unjustified, if not positively illegal, being based on misreading of evidence and on erroneous view of law. According to the submission, the appellant had neither lodged the F.I.R. nor otherwise instituted any criminal proceeding or falsely charged Izhar Hussain within the contemplation of s. 211, I.P.C.

arguments.claim: Prosecution under s.211 not barred by s.479A as not for perjury but for false charge.

anchor.surface_text: The counsel has in this connection expressly stated that he does not want to prosecute the appellant for any offence mentioned in s. 479-A, Cr.P.C. arguments.court_response: s.479A bars proceedings for false evidence; s.211 not applicable here anyway.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: g false evidence as a prosecution witness against an accused person during the companyrse of a criminal trial. To falsely charge must refer to the ori

arguments.claim: Giving false evidence as prosecution witness does not constitute 'falsely charges' under s.211 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: the expression falsely charges in this section, in our opinion, cannot mean giving false evidence as a prosecution witness against an accused person during the course of a criminal trial.

arguments.claim: 'Falsely charges' refers to initial accusation to set criminal law in motion, not witness testimony which is under ss.193/195 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: To falsely charge must refer to the original or initial accusation putting or seeking to put in motion the machinery of criminal investigation and not when seeking to prove the false charge by making deposition in support of the charge framed in that trial. ... Statement on oath falsely supporting the prosecution case against an accused person more appropriately amounts to an offence under ss. 193 and 195, I.P.C. and not under s. 211, I.P.C.

arguments.claim: Not expedient in interest of justice to prosecute; requires judicial discretion, only in glaring cases of deliberate falsehood.

anchor.surface_text: Every incorrect or false statement does not make it incumbent on the court to order prosecution. The court has to exercise judicial discretion in the light of all the relevant circumstances when it determines the question of expediency. ... It is only in glaring cases of deliberate falsehood where conviction is highly likely, that the court should direct prosecution.

arguments.claim: High Court lacked jurisdiction to direct complaint under s.195(3) CrPC as Additional DM court not subordinate to HC in that context; lower courts declined.
On revision, High Court cannot itself direct complaint after lower courts declined in judicial discretion.
Bar under s.479A(6) applies as trial court did not proceed under s.479A despite finding perjury.

In these circumstances ... the bar of clause (6) of Section 479-A clearly came into play.

holdings.text: The expression 'falsely charges' in Section 211 IPC cannot mean giving false evidence as a prosecution witness against an accused person during the course of a criminal trial.

anchor.surface_text: the expression falsely charges. in this section, in our opinion, cannot mean giving false evidence as a prosecution witness against an accused person during the course of a criminal trial.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive interpretation distinguishes 'falsely charges' from false testimony under ss.193/195 IPC; latter supports prosecution, former initiates it.

holdings.text: To falsely charge under Section 211 IPC must refer to the original or initial accusation putting or seeking to put in motion the machinery of criminal investigation and not deposition in support of the charge.

anchor.surface_text: To falsely charge must refer to the original or initial accusation putting or seeking to put in motion the machinery of criminal investigation and not when seeking to prove the false charge by making deposition in support of the charge framed in that trial.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words 'falsely charges' read with 'institution of criminal proceeding'; technical sense in criminal law requires intent to set law in motion via complaint or FIR.

holdings.text: Statement on oath falsely supporting the prosecution case against an accused person amounts to an offence under ss.193 and 195 IPC and not under s.211 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Statement on oath falsely supporting the prosecution case against an accused person more appropriately amounts to an offence under ss. 193 and 195, I.P.C. and not under s. 211, I.P.C.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature did not intend overlap between ss.193/195 (false evidence) and s.211 (false charge); offences distinct.

holdings.text: It is not expedient in the interest of justice to direct prosecution under s.211 IPC as every incorrect or false statement does not make it incumbent on the court to order prosecution; only in glaring cases of deliberate falsehood where conviction is highly likely.

anchor.surface_text: Every incorrect or false statement does number make it incumbent on the court to order prosecution. The court has to exercise judicial discretion in the light of all the relevant circumstances when it determines the question of expediency.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court exercises judicial discretion considering all circumstances; prosecution in larger interest of justice, not revenge; frequent prosecutions defeat object.

holdings.text: The High Court lacked jurisdiction to direct a complaint under s.195 CrPC as the Additional District Magistrate's court is not subordinate to the High Court under s.195(3) CrPC.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.195(3) defines subordination based on appeals; only trial or subordinate court can complain; expressed as doubt but supports reversal.

holdings.text: On revision under ss.435/439 CrPC, the High Court was not justified in itself directing filing of complaint after two lower courts declined in judicial discretion.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Revisional power does not allow substitution of discretion; at best remand for reconsideration if grave error.

holdings.text: Proceedings under s.476 CrPC are incompetent as the trial court did not record finding under s.479A CrPC at time of judgment despite disbelieving witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: Applying the said principle of law as laid down by their Lordships, it is obvious that the entire material was before the Court below and in spite of the fact that it arrived at the finding that the witness had perjured, it did number decide to proceed under Section 479-A...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Kuppa Goundan; s.479A requires contemporaneous finding; bar under s.479A(6) applies.
